conclusion: Understanding the problem setup of a conductor rod rotating in a magnetic field to find the power of the external force.
The setup includes a semi-circular conductor frame with radius r in a uniform magnetic field B, perpendicular to the plane.
The conductor rod OC can rotate around point O and is connected to a resistor R, with negligible resistance in the frame and rod.
Power is work done per unit time, P = dW/dt, and the external force does work against the induced emf.
The emf induced in the rotating rod is calculated using the formula ε = 1/2 B r^2 ω.
The current through R is I = ε/R = B r^2 ω / (2 R).
The power dissipated in the resistor R is P = I^2 R = B^2 r^4 ω^2 / (4 R).
The external force must do work at a rate equal to the power dissipated in the resistor.
The torque τ exerted by the external force equals the torque due to the magnetic force.
The torque due to the magnetic force is τ = B^2 r^4 ω / (4 R).
The power is torque times angular velocity, P = τ ω, resulting in P = B^2 r^4 ω^2 / (4 R).
The power of the external force is confirmed as B^2 r^4 ω^2 / (4 R).
Energy dissipated in the resistor per second is calculated again as P = B^2 r^4 ω^2 / (4 R).
